div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Havana Post, June 26, 1900
div1.p:
A General Order Printed in Mourning on
Death of Major Edmunds.

Major R. E. L. Michie, assistant adju-
tant general on the staff of General Lee,
has prepared and sent out an order on
the death of Major Edmunds. The order
is printed with the mourning border and
reads as follows:

“With profound sorrow the depart-
ment commander announces the death of
Major Frank H. Edmunds, First infantry,
acting inspector general of the depart-
ment, which occurred at Quemados, Cu-
ba, on this date. Major Edmunds was
born in the state of Michigan, appointed
to the military academy from Dakota,
graduated in 1871, and was appointed
second lieutenant, First infantry, in
which regiment he served until he was
appointed major of the Fifteenth infantry
on the 2d of March, 1899, being trans-
ferred back to the First infantry on the
18th of May of the same year.

“During the Spanish-American war he
was a Major and chief ordnance officer
from the 18th of July, 1898, until he
was honorably discharged from the
volunteer service on the 12th of May,
1899.

“He was appointed acting inspector
general and assigned to the staff of the
department commander on June 20,
1899, and has since served most satisfac-
torily in that capacity.

“The services of this accomplished and
well equipped officer are well known.
He was without fear and without re-
proach. His character was exalted, his
life pure. The army has lost one of its
best soldiers, his regiment one of its
truest members, the department a con-
scientious officer of inflexible integrity.
He has gone to his eternal rest without
a blot upon the polished armor of his
official record, and without a stain upon
a blameless private career.

“The usual badge of mourning will be
worn by members of the staff for thirty
days.

“By command of Brigadier-General
Lee, R. E. L. Michie, assistant adjutant
general.
